title: David Attenborough reveals he waited half a century to film rare monkey that features in new BBC series
text:

He is a TV legend whose amazing programmes have shaped how we think about the world around us.

For 67 years Sir David Attenborough’s fascinating series about the natural world have ­educated and entertained us all.

If there was a contest for the greatest living Briton, Sir David would be a strong contender.

And after bringing the wild world to our screens for so long you would think the 93-year-old has seen it all. But you’d be wrong.

His new seven-part BBC series, Seven Worlds, One Planet, covers new ground and reveals an animal Sir David has longed to track down since the 60s.

Back then he read a scientific paper about China’s golden ­snub-nosed monkey, a loner who lives in dense forest. But he could not get into China.

(Image: BBC Studios/Nick Green)

Sir David said: “It is a wonderful creature. I’ve never seen a film of it before. I always had it in the back of my mind and this lot (his crew) got it. The footage shows the ­monkeys have snubbed noses to stop them getting frostbitten.”

A dozing sloth, rare indri lemur and a nearly extinct bird of ­paradise also feature in the hour-long programmes that look at each of the seven continents.

Filming the series, which starts in the freezing, hostile Antarctica, was a huge task. A crew of more than 150 went on 80 expeditions in 41 countries and filmed more than 2,000 hours of footage.

(Image: BBC NHU/Alex Board)

Sir David said the challenge was to make the series distinctive.

He said: “Each of these ­continents has a different ­geological issue.

“They have ­different ways on how life has ­arrived there and how they survive in isolation.

“Every one of our shows has one or two sequences that take my breath away and have never been seen before.”

Among some of the gripping images in the series are shots of huge starfish under sea ice, a mum and baby orangutan and the once critically ­endangered Iberian lynx. There is also footage of cute Weddell seal pups and a ­colony of nervous gentoo ­penguins.

(Image: BBC/Nick Green)

(Image: BBC Studios/Fredi Devas)

Sir David said: “I would like the audience to appreciate how beautiful these things are. But also how they ­integrate with others and how we are dependent on them.

“Each continent has its own systems. Our influence is ­everywhere and we’ve made a tragic, desperate mess of it so far.

“But at last ­nations are coming ­together and recognising we all live on the same planet.

“All these ­seven worlds are one and we are ­dependent on it for every bit of food we eat and every breath we take.”

(Image: BBC Studios/Chadden Hunter)

Sir David’s programmes have hugely influenced how people see their world. Blue Planet 2 was crucial in raising awareness about plastics in seas.

But the film crew are very ­careful about how they interact with the natural environment.

Sir David said: “In some ­circumstances when the animal is in isolation, like a penguin, if it gets into trouble maybe you can help it and that’s OK.

(Image: BBC Studios/Fredi Devas)

“But when you have a ­cheetah stalking a baby ­antelope, if you interfere with it you are likely to cause more trouble than not.

“If you frighten the cheetah away, you frighten the ­antelope. The cheetah will be without its food and it will go and find another one.

“So you end up causing more problems if you don’t let ­nature takes its course. Those baby cheetahs have to feed so you have got to be careful that you know what you’re doing.”

Sir David, who was knighted in 1985, admitted he is ­finally slowing down. For the new series he ­travelled only to Kenya and Iceland.

He said: “I am reasonably active and I can walk around but I can’t walk for five hours a day with a heavy rucksack.

(Image: BBC NHU/Alex Board)

"I don’t think you should fly just for the hell of it. Apart from ­anything else the BBC would be absurd to spend money on unimportant air flights.

“I make television programmes. Before that I was a zoologist.

“To be able to spend my life combining those two things has been great luck.

“I really wanted to see a jungle. I thought there’d be ­monkeys hanging from every tree but it was not like that.

“I don’t have ­chemistry with animals particularly. It is easy to empathise with our closest relations but you can’t empathise with a millipede or a bird.”

David has no plans to retire and has TV ­projects lined up for 18 months.

He said: “When you are 93, 18 months is quite significant. Who knows what will happen. Your voice changes and if you are not careful, maybe it becomes aged. Maybe it has nothing to do with care.”

(Image: PA Wire/Press Association Images)

His wife Jane died in 1997 and daughter Susan helps run the house now.

He said: “Losing your wife is a traumatic and devastating experience. It changed my life profoundly. On the other hand my son and ­daughter were grown up and established in their careers.”

He said he was “very lucky” to have Susan helping him.

And despite his age, death is not a taboo subject.

He said of it: “I think nothing happens, to be truthful. I am ­working on that basis. I am not such an atheist that I say with ­confidence or true belief that there is no God.”

He recalled cutting open a termite mound to film ­inside and thinking the blind ­worker insects did not know what was happening.

He said: “They don’t have the ­senses. I can’t help think that we don’t have a particular sense. So I am ­resistant to saying without question ‘There is no God.’ I cannot say that.”

“Life is precious. I have had fantastic luck – doing this since the 50s.” Not as lucky as your audiences, Sir David.
description: EXCLUSIVE: The national treasure is back and he can't wait for viewers to see the elusive golden snub-nosed monkey
